Norwegian Wood

Adapted from celebrated Japanese author Haruki Murakami's novel, <em>Norwegian Wood</em> is, true to the book, a completely sensory film. With a soundtrack composed by Radiohead's Johnny Greenwood that makes it all the more evocative, this story revolves around huge and difficult-to-handle concepts such as death, loss, sex, and where love could fit into any of this

Source Code

t's been 10 years since <em>Donnie Darko</em> made a star out of Jake Gyllenhaal, so it seems quite appropriate that his new film is also one where a realistic character type is put into a scenario that's straight from the world of science fiction

Band of the Week: Butthole Surfers

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Sucker Punch

<em>Sucker Punch</em> is director Zack Snyder's (<em>300</em>, <em>Watchmen</em>) first original screenplay, and it certainly tells us a lot about him. He is clearly a visionary in the world of action movies, but sadly, he is not the greatest storyteller

Extraordinary event for ordinary people

It was an explosion of creative people joining together and working towards a common goal: to pin York on the fashion map

York DramaSoc at NSDF 2011

York's Drama Society have long had a good history with the annual National Student Drama Festival, and once again they are set to make it their stomping ground with the 2011 season just days away

The Movements: Art Nouveau

By James Bithell

Not often does an art movement come along which manifests itself so thoroughly in almost every area of design; Art Nouveau, however, fast became one such style at the turn of the 19th century

Band of the Week: Sparks

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Band of the Week: Beirut

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

The Lincoln Lawyer

The film is based on Michael Connelly's novel of the same name, and sets up a typically intriguing moral and legal conundrum, letting the audience and the cast loose to solve it. Matthew McConaughey portrays an arrogantly confident defence lawyer who does business from his car, forming a strong connection with those he represents

Battle: Los Angeles

You get the impression whilst watching <em>Battle: Los Angeles </em>that someone agreed to its production <em>extremely </em>early on. "Shaky-cam alien invasion? Sold! As long as it's PG-13..." The film doesn't seem to wish to justify itself beyond that definition

Archipelago

Hogg's writing and the excellent performances maintain the feeling of control, and yet the result is what you might call one of the most realistic British films in recent years. It shows a world that feels undocumented: that is, both the beautiful surroundings of the archipelago and the discord that comes between the siblings vacationing there

Band of the Week: TLC

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Alexander McQueen: a new wave of tribute

Just over a year on from the death of fashion great, Alexander McQueen, and his iconography is ever-growing. We take a look at the latest wave of tributes

That McQueen look

By James Bithell

The style set out by Alexander McQueen remains prevalent today. In this shoot we pick out the top high street looks to match it yourself

A newer, better vintage fair?

By James Bithell

York Does Vintage is a new alternative to the usual student haunt, Judy's Vintage Fair. Hannah Clugston checks out the new competitor, and likes what she sees

Hall Pass

It has more of a hopelessly romantic feel than the usual in-your-face gross-out comedy that the Farrelly brothers provide, but <em>Hall Pass</em> contains very few surprises

The Tempest

Part of Geoffrey Rush's character in <em>The King's Speech</em> involves him having once been a Shakespearean actor, who plays with his sons by pretending to be Caliban, a character from <em>The Tempest</em>, by stuffing a pillow in his jacket

Unknown

Looking at its poster, you'd be forgiven for thinking that <em>Unknown</em> was a sequel to <em>Taken</em>, the absurd 2008 action-thriller produced by Luc Besson that saw Liam Neeson running around Paris trying to find the man responsible for kidnapping his daughter

Nouse Albums Club - February '11

By James Bithell

Another month and another batch of reviews from Nouse's, ever-growing in numbers, underground music cabal.

Band of the Week: Squeeze

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Masters & Misfits

The first in-house production at the Theatre, Film and Television Department opened last night giving polished performances and ejecting raucous laughter from the audience. A double bill of comedy, the evening saw two French plays performed in parallel, offering different perspectives on the theme of class

Ramadan Amadeus

Tom Vickers' <em>Ramadan Amadeus</em> is an ambitious attempt to stylise the canonical <em>Faust</em> narrative in a novel way, but ultimately ends up chasing its own tale in the lengthy production. It is not without its merits - in the form of moments of inspired acting, and an enthused use of the drama barn itself - but it fell short of making a positive lasting impact

Riccardo Tisci confirmed as Dior chief designer

By James Bithell

The latest progression in the Galliano saga: his redundancy is confirmed, and Givenchy's Riccardo Tisci takes to the stand

London Fashion Week

"In difficult times fashion is always outrageous." Elsa Schiaparelli could very well have been talking last week, or at least far more recently than her long gone iconic era of the 1920's, as this certainly chimed in with this season's London Fashion Week (Thumbnail credit Photo: Fashion Mode)

The set designer: Rhea Thierstein

By James Bithell

Selfridges' Bright Young Thing, Rhea Thierstein, talks to Sarah Wolfe about her profession

Top Four

By James Bithell

Daniel Lismore pulses a strong beat to a fashion heart. We caught up with one of London's most fashionable to see what he had to say about the shows and who he is wearing

Catwalk

By James Bithell

Our pick of the best catwalks at this years London Fashion Week

Top Models

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em>'s pick of top models at London Fashion Week 2011

Fresh Fashion Faces

LFW hype centres around clothes, but models to parade them around need to be found somewhere. Sarah Wolfe talks to Milly Bee, fashion scout, about finding the right girls
